Primary experimental evidence (classic)
- Rosalind Franklin & R. Gosling, X‑ray diffraction (“Photo 51”): the X‑ray pattern shows the helical symmetry and the 3.4 Å base‑pair spacing and 34 Å helical pitch that led to the helix model. (Franklin & Gosling, Nature 1953). This is the crucial empirical image that shows DNA is helical.
- Watson & Crick, “Molecular structure of nucleic acids” (Nature 1953): proposed the double‑helix model that explains Franklin’s diffraction data and Chargaff’s rules.
- Chargaff’s compositional rules (A≈T, G≈C): independent biochemical evidence for complementary base pairing between two strands (see Chargaff’s papers/reviews; discussed in textbooks).
- Meselson & Stahl, “The replication of DNA in Escherichia coli” (PNAS 1958): semi‑conservative replication experiment — best explained by a double‑stranded DNA model.
Why these together matter: Franklin’s pattern shows a helix with specific dimensions; Chargaff’s ratios imply pairing between two complementary strands; Watson & Crick modeled hydrogen bonding that fits both; replication behaviour (Meselson–Stahl) is consistent with two complementary strands separating and copying.

High‑resolution structural confirmation
- X‑ray crystallography and NMR solve DNA duplex structures directly (many PDB entries). Example: the Dickerson dodecamer (PDB ID 1BNA) — a solved B‑DNA double helix at atomic resolution. (See RCSB PDB: https://www.rcsb.org/structure/1BNA)
- Modern crystallography/NMR papers and reviews confirm a family of helical forms (B‑DNA, A‑DNA, Z‑DNA) — all are helices, differing in geometry.

- Alberts et al., Molecular Biology of the Cell — chapter on DNA structure and replication (widely used, available via NCBI Bookshelf). Example link: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK21054/ (search the chapter “DNA structure and replication”).
- Nelson & Cox, Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry — clear, standard biochemistry text describing the double helix.
- Lodish et al., Molecular Cell Biology — standard cell/molecular bio text discussing DNA structure.
- Nature Education / Scitable: “DNA structure and function” — concise, student‑friendly overview: https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/dna-structure-and-function-395/
- Britannica entry on DNA for quick, citable public reference: https://www.britannica.com/science/DNA

- RCSB PDB pages for several DNA crystal structures (search “DNA” or specific PDB IDs).

Your friend is mistaken if they mean canonical cellular DNA — the standard structure you should study is the double helix (Watson–Crick model), not a single helix. Key points to know for a test:

- Basic architecture
  - DNA is normally two polynucleotide strands wound into a double helix.
  - Each strand has a sugar‑phosphate backbone (phosphodiester bonds) and nucleotide bases sticking inward.
  - Strands are antiparallel: one runs 5' → 3', the other 3' → 5'.

- Base pairing and specificity
  - Complementary base pairs: A pairs with T (2 hydrogen bonds); G pairs with C (3 hydrogen bonds).
  - Pairing is between a purine (A or G) and a pyrimidine (T or C), which preserves uniform helix width.

- Stabilizing interactions
  - Hydrogen bonds between bases + base‑stacking (van der Waals and hydrophobic interactions) stabilize the helix.
  - The sugar is deoxyribose (not ribose).

- Structural details (B‑DNA, the common form in cells)
  - Right‑handed helix.
  - About 10 base pairs per turn (≈10.5 in many conditions).
  - Rise ≈ 0.34 nm per base pair → ≈3.4 nm per turn.
  - Diameter ≈ 2 nm.
  - Major and minor grooves are important for protein binding.

- Other forms
  - A‑DNA: right‑handed, shorter/wider helix (seen in dehydrated samples and RNA‑DNA hybrids).
  - Z‑DNA: left‑handed zig‑zag backbone (can occur transiently, GC‑rich regions).

- When DNA can be single‑stranded
  - Some viruses have single‑stranded DNA genomes.
  - Cellular DNA becomes single‑stranded transiently during replication and transcription.
  - RNA is typically single‑stranded and forms internal secondary structures.
